Award.AwardTitle: Parallel Nonlinear Preconditioning Algorithms and Applications in Biomechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulation of fluid-structure interaction problems has many applications in science and engineering, such as the vibration analysis of aircraft, automobiles, and suspension bridges. More recently, the technique has been extended to diagnosing and treatment planning of certain medical problems such as congenital and acquired cardiovascular diseases, and to the design and optimization of medical devices. Solving the fluid-structure interaction problems on supercomputers with a large number of processor cores is challenging because the mathematical model consists of a coupled complicated nonlinear system, and most existing algorithms and software for the solution of problems of this kind do not scale well beyond a few hundred processor cores. The principal investigator will develop highly scalable algorithms and software that are suitable for large scale supercomputers and applicable for different models of blood flows and material parameters for the arterial wall.

Mature technologies are available for solving many types of linear problems, but for coupled, highly nonlinear multi-physics problems, robust and scalable techniques are badly needed, especially for implementation on large scale parallel computers. The technical focus of this project is a class of non-linearly preconditioned Newton methods that combines a nonlinear elimination technique with multilevel domain decomposition for parallelization. Through this research the principal investigator will solve non-linear difficult problems modeling a wide range of physical models with different levels of non-linearities. Algorithms that provide a high degree of parallelism will be designed so that large scale parallel computers can be used efficiently. The target application is a family of fluid-structure interaction problems in biomechanics. For the fluid model, both Newtonian and non-Newtonian models will be studied. For solid models, linear elasticity will be considered for small deformations, geometric nonlinear elasticity will be considered for large deformations, and hyper-elasticity will be considered for materially nonlinear problems. Two- and many-level versions of the algorithms will be investigated to obtain high scalability on parallel computers with a large number of processor cores. This research will have a great impact in areas of computational science and engineering where non-linear difficult problems need to be solved. The research is rich in opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students interested in applications in biomechanics, parallel computing, and general computational science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the project some nonlinearly preconditioned inexact Newton type algorithms are developed for the numerical solution of coupled systems of partial differential equations and the algorithms are applied to solving fluid and structural problems arising from computational biomechanics.  The nonlinear preconditioners are constructed based on an extension of the Gaussian elimination technique originally designed to solve linear matrix problems. By iteratively eliminating some highly nonlinear components, the algorithms enable the fast and robust convergence of the inexact Newton method. To parallelize the nonlinearly preconditioned method, the entire approach is embedded in a multilevel domain decomposition framework. The algorithm was tested successfully for three-dimensional fluid and solid problems defined on fully unstructured moving meshes. The basic algorithmic framework consists of an implicitly coupled system of two physical problems: a fluid model and a solid model. The fluid model is based on the three-dimensional unsteady incompressible Navier-Stokes equations. For the solid problem, several material models with increasing physical fidelity were studied. The simplest and fastest model is linear elasticity, however, the use of the hyperelasticity equation is more suitable for problems with large deformation and high material nonlinearity. A third, non-physical problem, is included in the coupled system to simulate the movement of the moving mesh on which the fluid equations are discretized. The implicitly coupled system of equations is discretized by a stabilized finite element method on a fully unstructured moving mesh and solved with a nonlinearly preconditioned inexact Newton type method in which the highly ill-conditioned linear Jacobian system is constructed analytically and is solved with a multilevel overlapping Schwarz type domain decomposition preconditioned Krylov subspace method.

Mature technologies are available for solving many types of linear problems, but for coupled, highly nonlinear multi-physics problems, robust and scalable techniques are badly needed, especially for large scale parallel computers. The algorithms introduced in the project  will have a great impact in the general areas of computational science and engineering where nonlinearly difficult problems need to be solved.
